qas.question: What is the first step that leads to a software failure?
What is the result of the programmer making a mistake?
When can software defects in dead code cause problems?

answers.text: run on a new computer hardware platform

plausible_answers.text: A programmer makes an error (mistake), which results in a defect (fault, bug) in the software source code.

qas.question: Software programs evolve through what process?
Defects in dead code always do what?
When the environment is changed, what does a failure always result from?

plausible_answers.text: a wide range of failure symptoms

qas.question: What can a single defect not result in?

context: Software faults occur through the following processes. <b3_0>A <a0_0>programmer makes an error<a0_0/> (mistake), which results in a <a1_0>defect (fault, bug)<a1_0/> in the software source code.<b3_0/> If this defect is executed, in certain situations the system will produce wrong results, causing a failure. Not all defects will necessarily result in <b4_0>failures<b4_0/>. For example, defects in dead code will never <b5_0>result in failures<b5_0/>. <b6_0>A defect<b6_0/> can turn into a failure when the environment is changed. Examples of these changes in environment include the software being <a2_0>run on a new computer hardware platform<a2_0/>, alterations in source data, or interacting with different software. A single defect may result in <b7_0>a wide range of failure symptoms<b7_0/>.
